text.p: Here are the highlights of stories in the Danish press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- There are at least 2,000 unemployed in the Copenhagen region who, although obliged to take job training or further education, are doing nothing.
--Sophus Berendsen caught the stock market napping on Thursday with a surprise announcement that it intended to split into two listed companies.
--Some 900 hourly-paid workers at hi-fi maker Bang & Olufsen stopped work on Thursday over a pay dispute. They are to meet on Saturday to discuss further action.
--Publisher Egmont's picture magazine He r& Nu (Here and Now) is doing well and posing stiff competition for Aller's Se & Hoer (See and Hear).
--Copenhagen's year as European cultural capital has left the organisers with debts at least 15 million crowns and the threat of bankruptcy.
--The transport board believes that more taxes are needed in order to reduce air pollution from vehicles.
--The planned Berendsen split will bring hidden value to light and create a windfall of billions of crowns for shareholders.
--April unemployment of 7.9 percent was the lowest in a decade.

--Den Danske Bank and Unibank expect to win back some 100 billion crowns in lost loan business by extending their telephone banking hours through the evenings and weekends. For example a housebuyer could ring on Sunday after viewing property and get a mortgage offer to compete with that offered by the estate agent.
